title: 114_s1528
content: The Department of Defense Energy Security Act of 2015 authorizes research to improve military vehicle technology for increased fuel economy or reduced fuel consumption in combat. The Secretary of Defense, in collaboration with the Army and Navy, may conduct research to enhance military vehicle technology for improved fuel economy in combat. Research will consider past successes and lessons from the Fuel Efficient Ground Vehicle Alpha and Bravo programs to develop technologies supporting increased fuel efficiency in light tactical vehicles. The Department of Defense is required to establish a repository for operational energy-related research and development efforts. The Secretary of Defense must establish a centralized repository for all operational energy-related research and development efforts by December 31, 2016. This repository will be accessible through a Department of Defense website for collaboration among employees and members of the Armed Forces involved in these efforts. The Secretary of Defense must establish a centralized repository for operational energy-related research and development efforts by December 31, 2016 to enable improved collaboration, sharing of best practices, lessons learned, and reduce redundancy. The Secretary of Defense is required to conduct a program to develop secure and reliable energy sources for military installations, including advanced energy metering, renewable energy, energy storage, and redundant power systems. Metrics will be developed to assess costs and benefits of these projects. Additionally, the Secretary is authorized to use the Energy Savings Investment Fund for energy management initiatives. Section 2919(b)(2) of title 10, United States Code, is amended by striking ``, to the extent provided for in an appropriations Act,''. Establishment of Department of Defense Alternative Fueled Vehicle Infrastructure Fund. Establishment of Fund in the Treasury named "Department of Defense Alternative Fuel Vehicle Infrastructure Fund" with deposits from appropriations, investments, and other sources. Secretary to invest surplus funds in government obligations. Funds available for use by Secretary through Under Secretary of Defense. The Department of Defense is authorized to establish and maintain alternative fuel dispensing stations and infrastructure for alternative fueled vehicles. Definitions for alternative fuel and alternative fueled vehicles are provided in the section. The Secretary of Defense is required to submit a report by September 30, 2016, on the costs and benefits of having 25 percent of National Guard and Reserve facilities equipped with a 21-day power storage capacity for disaster support. Additionally, there is a plan to enhance mission readiness through greater energy security at critical military installations. The Secretary of Defense must submit a report by September 30, 2016, outlining a plan to integrate energy storage, micro-grid technologies, and on-site power generation systems at military installations vulnerable to power interruptions. The report will be unclassified but may include a classified annex if needed. The term "congressional defense committees" is defined in this Act.
